channel.title: Comments on: Oona Eisenstadt on Boyarin’s Socrates and the Fat Rabbis
channel.description: notes on Jewish theology and spirituality

item.title: By: Daniel Boyarin
item.dc:creator: Daniel Boyarin
item.description: I find it absolutely telling that one bit of the critique is that Levinas is more interesting, while my reading of the Talmud may be "truer." I am not trying to be an interesting philosopher but to best characterize the Talmud. I find Levinas's readings as often as not nonsense vis-a-vis the text and am also not so impressed at their frequently racist and always sexist philosophical content either.

item.title: By: ssecunda
item.dc:creator: ssecunda
item.description: I don't have notes, but it was a general critique of Levinas. Instead of "essentializing," Boyarin "problematizies," etc. etc. I guess this is kind of obvious, in retrospect. If I'm not mistaken, the comment was elicited when someone in the audience brought up Levinas. I would add that Boyarin himself has repeatedly "apologized" for engaging in apologetics (one thinks especially of the introduction to Carnal Israel), but at the same time he always wants to get beyond apologetics. I think he may have seen Levinas as a sophisticated, un-apologetic apologist.

item.title: By: ssecunda
item.dc:creator: ssecunda
item.description: The Levinas comparison is interesting, but for other reasons as well. I attended a lecture at Yale where Boyarin explicitly pitted himself against Levinas' program (though it was a throwaway line), and then I heard him talk about it some more at a post lecture dinner.
